Article: Article 83: Qualifying Additional Tier 1 and Tier 2 capital issued by a special purpose entity
Content: Where the competent authority considers the assets of a special purpose entity other than its investment in the own funds of the parent undertaking or a subsidiary thereof that is included in the scope of consolidation pursuant to Chapter 2 of Title II of Part One, to be minimal and insignificant for such an entity, the competent authority may waive the condition specified in point (d) of the first subparagraph.

Article: Article 83: Qualifying Additional Tier 1 and Tier 2 capital issued by a special purpose entity
Content: 2. EBA shall develop draft regulatory technical standards to specify the types of assets that can relate to the operation of special purpose entities and the concepts of minimal and insignificant referred to in the second subparagraph of paragraph 1.

Article: Article 83: Qualifying Additional Tier 1 and Tier 2 capital issued by a special purpose entity
Content: EBA shall submit those draft regulatory technical standards to the Commission by 28 July 2013.

Article: Article 83: Qualifying Additional Tier 1 and Tier 2 capital issued by a special purpose entity
Content: Power is delegated to the Commission to adopt the regulatory technical standards referred to in the first subparagraph in accordance with Articles 10 to 14 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/ 2010.

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: 1. Institutions shall determine the amount of minority interests of a subsidiary that is included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital by subtracting from the minority interests of that undertaking the result of multiplying the amount referred to in point (a) by the percentage referred to in point (b):

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: (a) the Common Equity Tier 1 capital of the subsidiary minus the lower of the following:

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: (i) the amount of Common Equity Tier 1 capital of that subsidiary required to meet the sum of the requirement laid down in point (a) of Article 92(1), the requirements referred to in Articles 458 and 459, the specific own funds requirements referred to in Article 104 of Directive 2013/36/EU the combined buffer requirement defined in point (6) of Article 128 of Directive 2013/36/EU, the requirements referred to in Article 500 and any additional local supervisory regulations in third countries insofar as those requirements are to be met by Common Equity Tier 1 capital;

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: (ii) the amount of consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital that relates to that subsidiary that is required on a consolidated basis to meet the sum of the requirement laid down in point (a) of Article 92(1), the requirements referred to in Articles 458 and 459, the specific own funds requirements referred to in Article 104 of Directive 2013/36/EU, the combined buffer requirement defined in point (6) of Article 128 of Directive 2013/36/EU, the requirements referred to in Article 500 and any additional local supervisory regulations in third countries insofar as those requirements are to be met by Common Equity Tier 1 capital.

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: (b) the minority interests of the subsidiary expressed as a percentage of all Common Equity Tier 1 instruments of that undertaking plus the related share premium accounts, retained earnings and other reserves.

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: 2. The calculation referred to in paragraph 1 shall be undertaken on a sub-consolidated basis for each subsidiary referred to in Article 81(1).

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: An institution may choose not to undertake this calculation for a subsidiary referred to in Article 81(1). Where an institution takes such a decision, the minority interest of that subsidiary may not be included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital.

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: 3. Where a competent authority derogates from the application of prudential requirements on an individual basis, as laid down in Article 7, minority interest within the subsidiaries to which the waiver is applied shall not be recognised in own funds at the sub-consolidated or at the consolidated level, as applicable.

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: 4. EBA shall develop draft regulatory technical standards to specify the sub-consolidation calculation required in accordance with paragraph 2 of this Article, Articles 85 and 87.

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: EBA shall submit those draft regulatory technical standards to the Commission by 28 July 2013.

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: Power is delegated to the Commission to adopt the regulatory technical standards referred to in the first subparagraph in accordance with Articles 10 to 14 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/ 2010.

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: 5. Competent authorities may grant a waiver from the application of this Article to a parent financial holding company that satisfies all the following conditions:

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: (a) its principal activity is to acquire holdings;

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: (b) it is subject to prudential supervision on a consolidated basis;

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: (c) it consolidates a subsidiary institution in which it has only a minority holding by virtue of the control relationship defined in Article 1 of Directive 83/349/EEC;

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: (d) more than 90 % of the consolidated required Common Equity Tier 1 capital arises from the subsidiary institution referred to in point c) calculated on a sub-consolidated basis.

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: Where, after 28 June 2013, a parent financial holding company that meets the conditions laid down in the first subparagraph becomes a parent mixed financial holding company, competent authorities may grant the waiver referred to in the first subparagraph to that parent mixed financial holding company provided that it meets the conditions laid down in that subparagraph.

Article: Article 84: Minority interests included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital
Content: 6. Where credit institutions permanently affiliated in a network to a central body and institutions established within an institutional protection scheme subject to the conditions laid down in Article 113(7) have set up a cross-guarantee scheme that provides that there is no current or foreseen material, practical or legal impediment to the transfer of the amount of own funds above the regulatory requirements from the counterparty to the credit institution, these institutions are exempted from the provisions of this Article regarding deductions and may recognise any minority interest arising within the cross-guarantee scheme in full.

Article: Article 85: Qualifying Tier 1 instruments included in consolidated Tier 1 capital
Content: 1. Institutions shall determine the amount of qualifying Tier 1 capital of a subsidiary that is included in consolidated own funds by subtracting from the qualifying Tier 1 capital of that undertaking the result of multiplying the amount referred to in point (a) by the percentage referred to in point (b):

Article: Article 85: Qualifying Tier 1 instruments included in consolidated Tier 1 capital
Content: (a) the Tier 1 capital of the subsidiary minus the lower of the following:

Article: Article 85: Qualifying Tier 1 instruments included in consolidated Tier 1 capital
Content: (i) the amount of Tier 1 capital of the subsidiary required to meet the sum of the requirement laid down in point (b) of Article 92(1), the requirements referred to in Articles 458 and 459, the specific own funds requirements referred to in Article 104 of Directive 2013/36/EU, the combined buffer requirement defined in point (6) of Article 128 of Directive 2013/36/EU, the requirements referred to in Article 500 and any additional local supervisory regulations in third countries insofar as those requirements are to be met by Tier 1 Capital;

Article: Article 85: Qualifying Tier 1 instruments included in consolidated Tier 1 capital
Content: (ii) the amount of consolidated Tier 1 capital that relates to the subsidiary that is required on a consolidated basis to meet the sum of the requirement laid down in point (b) of Article 92(1), the requirements referred to in Articles 458 and 459, the specific own funds requirements referred to in Article 104 of Directive 2013/36/EU, the combined buffer requirement defined in point (6) of Article 128 of Directive 2013/36/EU, the requirements referred to in Article 500 and any additional local supervisory regulations in third countries insofar as those requirements are to be met by Tier 1 Capital;

Article: Article 85: Qualifying Tier 1 instruments included in consolidated Tier 1 capital
Content: (b) the qualifying Tier 1 capital of the subsidiary expressed as a percentage of all Tier 1 instruments of that undertaking plus the related share premium accounts, retained earnings and other reserves.

Article: Article 85: Qualifying Tier 1 instruments included in consolidated Tier 1 capital
Content: 2. The calculation referred to in paragraph 1 shall be undertaken on a sub-consolidated basis for each subsidiary referred to in Article 81(1).

Article: Article 85: Qualifying Tier 1 instruments included in consolidated Tier 1 capital
Content: An institution may choose not to undertake this calculation for a subsidiary referred to in Article 81(1). Where an institution takes such a decision, the qualifying Tier 1 capital of that subsidiary may not be included in consolidated Tier 1 capital.

Article: Article 85: Qualifying Tier 1 instruments included in consolidated Tier 1 capital
Content: 3. Where a competent authority derogates from the application of prudential requirements on an individual basis, as laid down in Article 7, Tier 1 instruments within the subsidiaries to which the waiver is applied shall not be recognised as own funds at the sub-consolidated or at the consolidated level, as applicable.

Article: Article 86: Qualifying Tier 1 capital included in consolidated Additional Tier 1 capital
Content: Without prejudice to Article 84 (5) or (6), institutions shall determine the amount of qualifying Tier 1 capital of a subsidiary that is included in consolidated Additional Tier 1 capital by subtracting from the qualifying Tier 1 capital of that undertaking included in consolidated Tier 1 capital the minority interests of that undertaking that are included in consolidated Common Equity Tier 1 capital.

Article: Article 87: Qualifying own funds included in consolidated own funds
Content: 1. Institutions shall determine the amount of qualifying own funds of a subsidiary that is included in consolidated own funds by subtracting from the qualifying own funds of that undertaking the result of multiplying the amount referred to in point (a) by the percentage referred to in point (b):

Article: Article 87: Qualifying own funds included in consolidated own funds
Content: (a) the own funds of the subsidiary minus the lower of the following:

Article: Article 87: Qualifying own funds included in consolidated own funds
Content: (i) the amount of own funds of the subsidiary required to meet the sum of the requirement laid down in point (c) of Article 92(1), the requirements referred to in Articles 458 and 459, the specific own funds requirements referred to in Article 104 of Directive 2013/36/EU, the combined buffer requirement defined in point (6) of Article 128 of Directive 2013/36/EU, the requirements referred to in Article 500 and any additional local supervisory regulations in third countries;

Article: Article 87: Qualifying own funds included in consolidated own funds
Content: (ii) the amount of own funds that relates to the subsidiary that is required on a consolidated basis to meet the sum of the requirement laid down in point (c) of Article 92 (1), the requirements referred to in Articles 458 and 459, the specific own funds requirements referred to in Article 104 of Directive 2013/36/EU, the combined buffer requirement defined in point (6) of Article 128 of Directive 2013/36/EU, the requirements referred to in Article 500 and any additional local supervisory own funds requirement in third countries;

Article: Article 87: Qualifying own funds included in consolidated own funds
Content: (b) the qualifying own funds of the undertaking, expressed as a percentage of all own funds instruments of the subsidiary that are included in Common Equity Tier 1, Additional Tier 1 and Tier 2 items and the related share premium accounts, the retained earnings and other reserves.

Article: Article 87: Qualifying own funds included in consolidated own funds
Content: 2. The calculation referred to in paragraph 1 shall be undertaken on a sub-consolidated basis for each subsidiary referred to in Article 81(1).

Article: Article 87: Qualifying own funds included in consolidated own funds
Content: An institution may choose not to undertake this calculation for a subsidiary referred to in Article 81(1). Where an institution takes such a decision, the qualifying own funds of that subsidiary may not be included in consolidated own funds.

Article: Article 87: Qualifying own funds included in consolidated own funds
Content: 3. Where a competent authority derogates from the application of prudential requirements on an individual basis, as laid down in Article 7, own funds instruments within the subsidiaries to which the waiver is applied shall not be recognised as own funds at the sub-consolidated or at the consolidated level, as applicable.

Article: Article 88: Qualifying own funds instruments included in consolidated Tier 2 capital
Content: Without prejudice to Article 84(5) or (6), institutions shall determine the amount of qualifying own funds of a subsidiary that is included in consolidated Tier 2 capital by subtracting from the qualifying own funds of that undertaking that are included in consolidated own funds the qualifying Tier 1 capital of that undertaking that is included in consolidated Tier 1 capital.

Title: TITLE III: QUALIFYING HOLDINGS OUTSIDE THE FINANCIAL SECTOR

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: 1. A qualifying holding, the amount of which exceeds 15 % of the eligible capital of the institution, in an undertaking which is not one of the following shall be subject to the provisions laid down in paragraph 3:

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: (a) a financial sector entity;

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: (b) an undertaking, that is not a financial sector entity, carrying on activities which the competent authority considers to be any of the following:

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: (i) a direct extension of banking;

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: (ii) ancillary to banking;

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: (iii) leasing, factoring, the management of unit trusts, the management of data processing services or any other similar activity.

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: 2. The total amount of the qualifying holdings of an institution in undertakings other than those referred to in points (a) and (b) of paragraph 1 that exceeds 60 % of its eligible capital shall be subject to the provisions laid down in paragraph 3.

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: 3. Competent authorities shall apply the requirements laid down in point (a) or (b) to qualifying holdings of institutions referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2:

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: (a) for the purpose of calculating the capital requirement in accordance with Part Three, institutions shall apply a risk weight of 1 250 % to the greater of the following:

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: (i) the amount of qualifying holdings referred to in paragraph 1 in excess of 15 % of eligible capital;

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: (ii) the total amount of qualifying holdings referred to in paragraph 2 that exceed 60 % of the eligible capital of the institution;

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: (b) the competent authorities shall prohibit institutions from having qualifying holdings referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 the amount of which exceeds the percentages of eligible capital laid down in those paragraphs.

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: Competent authorities shall publish their choice of (a) or (b).

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: 4. For the purposes of point (b) of paragraph 1, EBA shall issue guidelines specifying the following concepts:

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: (a) activities that are a direct extension of banking;

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: (b) activities ancillary to banking;

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: (c) similar activities.

Article: Article 89: Risk weighting and prohibition of qualifying holdings outside the financial sector
Content: Those guidelines shall be adopted in accordance with Article 16 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010.

Article: Article 90: Alternative to 1 250 % risk weight
Content: As an alternative to applying a 1 250 % risk weight to the amounts in excess of the limits specified in Article 89(1) and (2), institutions may deduct those amounts from Common Equity Tier 1 items in accordance with point (k) of Article 36 (1).

Article: Article 91: Exceptions
Content: 1. Shares of undertakings not referred to in points (a) and (b) of Article 89(1) shall not be included in calculating the eligible capital limits specified in that Article where any of the following conditions is met:

Article: Article 91: Exceptions
Content: (a) those shares are held temporarily during a financial assistance operation as referred to in Article 79;

Article: Article 91: Exceptions
Content: (b) the holding of those shares is an underwriting position held for five working days or fewer;

Article: Article 91: Exceptions
Content: (c) those shares are held in the own name of the institution and on behalf of others.

Article: Article 91: Exceptions
Content: 2. Shares which are not financial fixed assets as referred to in Article 35(2) of Directive 86/635/EEC shall not be included in the calculation specified in Article 89.

Title: TITLE I: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS, VALUATION AND REPORTING

Chapter: CHAPTER 1: Required level of own funds

Section: Section 1: Own funds requirements for institutions

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: 1.   Subject to Articles 93 and 94, institutions shall at all times satisfy the following own funds requirements:

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (a) a Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio of 4,5 %;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (b) a Tier 1 capital ratio of 6 %;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (c) a total capital ratio of 8 %.

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: 2.   Institutions shall calculate their capital ratios as follows:

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (a) the Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio is the Common Equity Tier 1 capital of the institution expressed as a percentage of the total risk exposure amount;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (b) the Tier 1 capital ratio is the Tier 1 capital of the institution expressed as a percentage of the total risk exposure amount;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (c) the total capital ratio is the own funds of the institution expressed as a percentage of the total risk exposure amount.

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: 3.   Total risk exposure amount shall be calculated as the sum of points (a) to (f) of this paragraph after taking into account the provisions laid down in paragraph 4:

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (a) the risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit risk and dilution risk, calculated in accordance with Title II and Article 379, in respect of all the business activities of an institution, excluding risk-weighted exposure amounts from the trading book business of the institution;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (b) the own funds requirements, determined in accordance with Title IV of this Part or Part Four, as applicable, for the trading-book business of an institution, for the following:

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (i) position risk;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (ii) large exposures exceeding the limits specified in Articles 395 to 401, to the extent an institution is permitted to exceed those limits;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (c) the own funds requirements determined in accordance with Title IV or Title V with the exception of Article 379, as applicable, for the following:

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (i) foreign-exchange risk;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (ii) settlement risk;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (iii) commodities risk;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (d) the own funds requirements calculated in accordance with Title VI for credit valuation adjustment risk of OTC derivative instruments other than credit derivatives recognised to reduce risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit risk;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (e) the own funds requirements determined in accordance with Title III for operational risk;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (f) the risk-weighted exposure amounts determined in accordance with Title II for counterparty risk arising from the trading book business of the institution for the following types of transactions and agreements:

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (i) contracts listed in Annex II and credit derivatives;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (ii) repurchase transactions, securities or commodities lending or borrowing transactions based on securities or commodities;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (iii) margin lending transactions based on securities or commodities;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (iv) long settlement transactions.

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: 4.   The following provisions shall apply in the calculation of the total risk exposure amount referred to in paragraph 3:

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (a) the own funds requirements referred to in points (c), (d) and (e) of that paragraph shall include those arising from all the business activities of an institution;

Article: Article 92: Own funds requirements
Content: (b) institutions shall multiply the own funds requirements set out in points (b) to (e) of that paragraph by 12,5.

Article: Article 93: Initial capital requirement on going concern
Content: 1.   The own funds of an institution may not fall below the amount of initial capital required at the time of its authorisation.

Article: Article 93: Initial capital requirement on going concern
Content: 2.   Credit institutions that were already in existence on 1 January 1993, the amount of own funds of which do not attain the amount of initial capital required may continue to carry out their activities. In that event, the amount of own funds of those institutions may not fall below the highest level reached with effect from 22 December 1989.

Article: Article 93: Initial capital requirement on going concern
Content: 3.   Authorised investment firms and firms that were covered by Article 6 of Directive 2006/49/EC which were in existence before 31 December 1995, the amount of own funds of which do not attain the amount of initial capital required may continue to carry out their activities. The own funds of such firms or investment firms shall not fall below the highest reference level calculated after the date of notification contained in Council Directive 93/6/EEC of 15 March 1993 on the capital adequacy of investments firms and credit institutions (28). That reference level shall be the average daily level of own funds calculated over a six month period preceding the date of calculation. It shall be calculated every six months in respect of the corresponding preceding period.

Article: Article 93: Initial capital requirement on going concern
Content: 4.   Where control of an institution falling within the category referred to in paragraph 2 or 3 is taken by a natural or legal person other than the person who controlled the institution previously, the amount of own funds of that institution shall attain the amount of initial capital required.

Article: Article 93: Initial capital requirement on going concern
Content: 5.   Where there is a merger of two or more institutions falling within the category referred to in paragraph 2 or 3, the amount of own funds of the institution resulting from the merger shall not fall below the total own funds of the merged institutions at the time of the merger, as long as the amount of initial capital required has not been attained.

Article: Article 93: Initial capital requirement on going concern
Content: 6.   Where competent authorities consider it necessary to ensure the solvency of an institution that the requirement laid down in paragraph 1 is met, the provisions laid down in paragraphs 2 to 5 shall not apply.

Article: Article 94: Derogation for small trading book business
Content: 1.   Institutions may replace the capital requirement referred to in point (b) of Article 92(3) by a capital requirement calculated in accordance with point (a) of that paragraph in respect of their trading-book business, provided that the size of their on- and off-balance sheet trading-book business meets both the following conditions:

Article: Article 94: Derogation for small trading book business
Content: (a) it is normally less than 5 % of the total assets and EUR 15 million;

Article: Article 94: Derogation for small trading book business
Content: (b) it never exceeds 6 % of total assets and EUR 20 million.

Article: Article 94: Derogation for small trading book business
Content: 2.   In calculating the size of on- and off-balance sheet business, institutions shall apply the following:

Article: Article 94: Derogation for small trading book business
Content: (a) debt instruments shall be valued at their market prices or their nominal values, equities at their market prices and derivatives according to the nominal or market values of the instruments underlying them;

Article: Article 94: Derogation for small trading book business
Content: (b) the absolute value of long positions shall be summed with the absolute value of short positions.

Article: Article 94: Derogation for small trading book business
Content: 3.   Where an institution fails to meet the condition in point (b) of paragraph 1 it shall immediately notify the competent authority. If, following assessment by the competent authority, the competent authority determines and notifies the institution that the requirement in point (a) of paragraph 1 is not met, the institution shall cease to make use of paragraph 1 from the next reporting date.

Section: Section 2: Own funds requirements for investment firms with limited authorisation to provide investment...

Article: Article 95: Own funds requirements for investment firms with limited authorisation to provide investment...
Content: 1. For the purposes of Article 92(3), investment firms that

Article: Article 95: Own funds requirements for investment firms with limited authorisation to provide investment...
Content: are not authorised to provide the investment services and activities listed in points (3) and (6) of Section A of Annex I to

Article 96: Own funds requirements for investment firms which hold initial capital as laid down in Article 28(2...
Content: 1.   For the purposes of Article 92(3), the following categories of investment firm which hold initial capital in accordance with Article 28(2) of Directive 2013/36/EU shall use the calculation of the total risk exposure amount specified in paragraph 2 of this Article:

Article: Article 96: Own funds requirements for investment firms which hold initial capital as laid down in Article 28(2...
Content: (a) investment firms that deal on own account only for the purpose of fulfilling or executing a client order or for the purpose of gaining entrance to a clearing and settlement system or a recognised exchange when acting in an agency capacity or executing a client order;

Article: Article 96: Own funds requirements for investment firms which hold initial capital as laid down in Article 28(2...
Content: (b) investment firms that meet all the following conditions:

Article: Article 96: Own funds requirements for investment firms which hold initial capital as laid down in Article 28(2...
Content: (i) they do not hold client money or securities;

Article: Article 96: Own funds requirements for investment firms which hold initial capital as laid down in Article 28(2...
Content: (ii) they undertake only dealing on own account;

Article: Article 96: Own funds requirements for investment firms which hold initial capital as laid down in Article 28(2...
Content: (iii) they have no external customers;

Article: Article 96: Own funds requirements for investment firms which hold initial capital as laid down in Article 28(2...
Content: (iv) their execution and settlement transactions take place under the responsibility of a clearing institution and are guaranteed by that clearing institution.

Article: Article 96: Own funds requirements for investment firms which hold initial capital as laid down in Article 28(2...
Content: 2.   For investment firms referred to in paragraph 1, total risk exposure amount shall be calculated as the sum of the following:

Article: Article 96: Own funds requirements for investment firms which hold initial capital as laid down in Article 28(2...
Content: (a) points (a) to (d) and (f) of Article 92(3) after applying Article 92(4);

Article: Article 96: Own funds requirements for investment firms which hold initial capital as laid down in Article 28(2...
Content: (b) the amount referred to in Article 97 multiplied by 12,5.

Article: Article 96: Own funds requirements for investment firms which hold initial capital as laid down in Article 28(2...
Content: 3.   Investment firms referred to in paragraph 1 are subject to all other provisions regarding operational risk laid down in Title VII, Chapter 3, Section II, Sub-section 1 of Directive 2013/36/EU.

Article: Article 97: Own Funds based on Fixed Overheads
Content: 1. In accordance with Articles 95 and 96, an investment firm and firms referred to in point (2)(c) of Article 4(1) that provide the investment services and activities listed in points (2) and (4) of Section A of Annex I to Directive 2004/39/EC shall hold eligible capital of at least one quarter of the fixed overheads of the preceding year.

Article: Article 97: Own Funds based on Fixed Overheads
Content: 2. Where there is a change in the business of an investment firm since the preceding year that the competent authority considers to be material, the competent authority may adjust the requirement laid down in paragraph 1.

Article: Article 97: Own Funds based on Fixed Overheads
Content: 3. Where an investment firm has not completed business for one year, starting from the day it starts up, an investment firm shall hold eligible capital of at least one quarter of the fixed overheads projected in its business plan, except where the competent authority requires the business plan to be adjusted.

Article: Article 97: Own Funds based on Fixed Overheads
Content: 4. EBA in consultation with ESMA shall develop draft regulatory technical standards to specify in greater detail the following:

Article: Article 97: Own Funds based on Fixed Overheads
Content: (a) the calculation of the requirement to hold eligible capital of at least one quarter of the fixed overheads of the previous year;

Article: Article 97: Own Funds based on Fixed Overheads
Content: (b) the conditions for the adjustment by the competent authority of the requirement to hold eligible capital of at least one quarter of the fixed overheads of the previous year;

Article: Article 97: Own Funds based on Fixed Overheads
Content: (c) the calculation of projected fixed overheads in the case of an investment firm that has not completed business for one year.

Article: Article 97: Own Funds based on Fixed Overheads
Content: EBA shall submit those draft regulatory technical standards to the Commission by 1 March 2014.

Article: Article 97: Own Funds based on Fixed Overheads
Content: Power is delegated to the Commission to adopt the regulatory technical standards referred to in the first subparagraph in accordance with Articles 10 to 14 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/ 2010.

Article: Article 98: Own funds for investment firms on a consolidated basis
Content: 1. In the case of the investment firms referred to in Article 95(1) in a group, where that group does not include credit institutions, a parent investment firm in a Member State shall apply Article 92 at a consolidated level as follows:

Article: Article 98: Own funds for investment firms on a consolidated basis
Content: (a) using the calculation of total risk exposure amount specified in Article 95(2);

Article: Article 98: Own funds for investment firms on a consolidated basis
Content: (b) own funds calculated on the basis of the consolidated situation of the parent investment firm or that of the financial holding company or mixed financial holding company, as applicable

Article: Article 98: Own funds for investment firms on a consolidated basis
Article 98: Own funds for investment firms on a consolidated basis
Content: 2. In the case of investment firms referred to in Article 96(1) in a group, where that group does not include credit institutions, a parent investment firm in a Member State and an investment firm controlled by a financial holding company or mixed financial holding company shall apply Article 92 on a consolidated basis as follows:

Article: Article 98: Own funds for investment firms on a consolidated basis
Content: (a) it shall use the calculation of total risk exposure amount specified in Article 96(2);

Article: Article 98: Own funds for investment firms on a consolidated basis
Content: (b) it shall use own funds calculated on the basis of the consolidated situation of the parent investment firm or that of the financial holding company or mixed financial holding company, as applicable, and in compliance with Chapter 2 of Title II of Part One.

Article: Article 99: Reporting on own funds requirements and financial information
Content: 1. Reporting by institutions to the competent authorities on the obligations laid down in Article 92 shall be carried out at least on a semi-annual basis.

Article: Article 99: Reporting on own funds requirements and financial information
Content: 2. Institutions subject to Article 4 of Regulation (EC) No 1606/2002 and credit institutions other than those referred to in Article 4 of that Regulation that prepare their consolidated accounts in conformity with the international accounting standards adopted in accordance with the procedure laid down in Article 6(2) of that Regulation, shall also report financial information.

Article: Article 99: Reporting on own funds requirements and financial information
Content: 3. Competent authorities may require those credit institutions applying international accounting standards as applicable under Regulation (EC) No 1606/2002 for the reporting of own funds on a consolidated basis pursuant to Article 24(2) of this Regulation to also report financial information as laid down in paragraph 2 of this Article.

Article: Article 99: Reporting on own funds requirements and financial information
Content: 4. The financial information referred to in paragraphs 2 and 3 shall be reported to the extent this is necessary to obtain a comprehensive view of the risk profile of an institution's activities and a view on the systemic risks posed by institutions to the financial sector or the real economy in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010.

Article: Article 99: Reporting on own funds requirements and financial information
Content: 5. EBA shall develop draft implementing technical standards to specify the uniform formats, frequencies, dates of reporting, definitions and the IT solutions to be applied in the Union for the reporting referred to in paragraphs 1 to 4.

Article: Article 99: Reporting on own funds requirements and financial information
Content: The reporting requirements shall be proportionate to the nature, scale and complexity of the activities of the institutions.

Article: Article 99: Reporting on own funds requirements and financial information
Content: EBA shall submit those draft implementing technical standards to the Commission by 28 July 2013.

Article: Article 99: Reporting on own funds requirements and financial information
Content: Power is conferred on the Commission to adopt the implementing technical standards referred to in the first subparagraph in accordance with Article 15 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/ 2010.

Article: Article 99: Reporting on own funds requirements and financial information
Content: 6. Where a competent authority considers that the financial information required by paragraph 2 is necessary to obtain a comprehensive view of the risk profile of the activities of, and a view of the systemic risks to the financial sector or the real economy posed by, institutions other than those referred to in paragraphs 2 and 3 that are subject to an accounting framework based on Directive 86/635/EEC, the competent authority shall consult EBA on the extension of the reporting requirements of financial information on a consolidated basis to those institutions, provided that they are not already reporting on such a basis.

Article: Article 99: Reporting on own funds requirements and financial information
Content: EBA shall develop draft implementing technical standards to specify the formats to be used by institutions to which the competent authorities may extend the reporting requirements in accordance with the first subparagraph.

Article: Article 99: Reporting on own funds requirements and financial information
Content: EBA shall submit those draft implementing technical standards to the Commission by 28 July 2013.

Article: Article 99: Reporting on own funds requirements and financial information
Content: 7. Where a competent authority considers information not covered by the implementing technical standards referred to in paragraph 5 to be necessary for the purposes set out in paragraph 4, it shall notify EBA and the ESRB of the additional information it deems necessary to include in the implementing technical standards referred to in paragraph 5.

Article: Article 100: Additional reporting requirements
Content: Institutions shall report to the competent authorities the level, at least in aggregate terms, of their repurchase agreements, securities lending and all forms of encumbrance of assets.

Article: Article 100: Additional reporting requirements
Content: EBA shall include this information in the implementing technical standards on reporting referred to in Article 99(5).

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: 1. Institutions shall report on a semi-annual basis the following data to the competent authorities for each national immovable property market to which they are exposed:

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: (a) losses stemming from exposures for which an institution has recognised residential property as collateral, up to the lower of the pledged amount and 80 % of the market value or 80 % of the mortgage lending value unless otherwise decided under Article 124(2);

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: (b) overall losses stemming from exposures for which an institution has recognised residential property as collateral, up to the part of the exposure treated as fully secured by residential property in accordance with Article 124(1);

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: (c) the exposure value of all outstanding exposures for which an institution has recognised residential property as collateral limited to the part treated as fully secured by residential property in accordance with Article 124(1);

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: (d) losses stemming from exposures for which an institution has recognised immovable commercial property as collateral, up to the lower of the pledged amount and 50 % of the market value or 60 % of the mortgage lending value unless otherwise decided under Article 124(2);

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: (e) overall losses stemming from exposures for which an institution has recognised immovable commercial property as collateral, up to the part of the exposure treated as fully secured by immovable commercial property in accordance with Article 124(1).

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: (f) the exposure value of all outstanding exposures for which an institution has recognised immovable commercial property as collateral limited to the part treated as fully secured by immovable commercial property in accordance with Article 124(1).

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: 2. The data referred to in paragraph 1 shall be reported to the competent authority of the home Member State of the relevant institution. Where an institution has a branch in another Member State, the data relating to that branch shall also be reported to the competent authorities of the host Member State. The data shall be reported separately for each immovable property market within the Union to which the relevant institution is exposed.

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: 3. The competent authorities shall publish annually on an aggregated basis the data specified in points (a) to (f) of paragraph 1, together with historical data, where available. A competent authority shall, upon the request of another competent authority in a Member State or EBA provide to that competent authority or EBA more detailed information on the condition of the residential property or commercial immovable property markets in that Member State.

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: 4. EBA shall develop draft implementing technical standards to specify the following:

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: (a) uniform formats, definitions, frequencies and dates of reporting, as well as the IT solutions, of the items referred to in paragraph 1;

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: (b) uniform formats, definitions, frequencies and dates of reporting, as well as IT solutions, of the aggregate data referred to in paragraph 2.

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: EBA shall submit those draft implementing technical standards to the Commission by 28 July 2013.

Article: Article 101: Specific reporting obligations
Content: Power is conferred on the Commission to adopt the implementing technical standards referred to in the first subparagraph in accordance with Article 15 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/ 2010.

Article: Article 102: Requirements for the trading book
Content: 1. Positions in the trading book shall be either free of restrictions on their tradability or able to be hedged.

Article: Article 102: Requirements for the trading book
Content: 2. Trading intent shall be evidenced on the basis of the strategies, policies and procedures set up by the institution to manage the position or portfolio in accordance with Article 103.

Article: Article 102: Requirements for the trading book
Content: 3. Institutions shall establish and maintain systems and controls to manage their trading book in accordance with Articles 104 and 105.

Article: Article 102: Requirements for the trading book
Content: 4. Institutions may include internal hedges in the calculation of capital requirements for position risk provided that they are held with trading intent and that the requirements of Articles 103 to 106 are met.

Article: Article 103: Management of the trading book
Content: In managing its positions or sets of positions in the trading book the institution shall comply with all of the following requirements:

Article: Article 103: Management of the trading book
Content: (a) the institution shall have in place a clearly documented trading strategy for the position/instrument or portfolios, approved by senior management, which shall include the expected holding period;

Article: Article 103: Management of the trading book
Content: (b) the institution shall have in place clearly defined policies and procedures for the active management of positions entered into on a trading desk. Those policies and procedures shall include the following:

Article: Article 103: Management of the trading book
Content: (i) which positions may be entered into by which trading desk;

Article: Article 103: Management of the trading book
Content: (ii) position limits are set and monitored for appropriateness;

Article: Article 103: Management of the trading book
Content: (iii) dealers have the autonomy to enter into and manage the position within agreed limits and according to the approved strategy;

Article: Article 103: Management of the trading book
Content: (iv) positions are reported to senior management as an integral part of the institution's risk management process;

Article: Article 103: Management of the trading book
Content: (v) positions are actively monitored with reference to market information sources and an assessment made of the marketability or hedgeability of the position or its component risks, including the assessment, the quality and availability of market inputs to the valuation process, level of market turnover, sizes of positions traded in the market;

Article: Article 103: Management of the trading book
Content: (vi) active anti-fraud procedures and controls.

Article: Article 103: Management of the trading book
Content: (c) the institution shall have in place clearly defined policies and procedures to monitor the positions against the institution's trading strategy including the monitoring of turnover and positions for which the originally intended holding period has been exceeded.

Article: Article 104: Inclusion in the trading book
Content: 1. Institutions shall have in place clearly defined policies and procedures for determining which position to include in the trading book for the purposes of calculating their capital requirements, in accordance with the requirements set out in Article 102 and the definition of trading book in accordance with point (86) of Article 4(1), taking into account the institution's risk management capabilities and practices. The institution shall fully document its compliance with these policies and procedures and shall subject them to periodic internal audit.

Article: Article 104: Inclusion in the trading book
Content: 2. Institutions shall have in place clearly defined policies and procedures for the overall management of the trading book. These policies and procedures shall at least address:

Article: Article 104: Inclusion in the trading book
Content: (a) the activities the institution considers to be trading and as constituting part of the trading book for own funds requirement purposes;

Article: Article 104: Inclusion in the trading book
Content: (b) the extent to which a position can be marked-to-market daily by reference to an active, liquid two-way market;

Article: Article 104: Inclusion in the trading book
Content: (c) for positions that are marked-to-model, the extent to which the institution can:

Article: Article 104: Inclusion in the trading book
Content: (i) identify all material risks of the position;

Article: Article 104: Inclusion in the trading book
Content: (ii) hedge all material risks of the position with instruments for which an active, liquid two-way market exists;

Article: Article 104: Inclusion in the trading book
Content: (iii) derive reliable estimates for the key assumptions and parameters used in the model;

Article: Article 104: Inclusion in the trading book
Content: (d) the extent to which the institution can, and is required to, generate valuations for the position that can be validated externally in a consistent manner;

Article: Article 104: Inclusion in the trading book
Content: (e) the extent to which legal restrictions or other operational requirements would impede the institution's ability to effect a liquidation or hedge of the position in the short term;

Article: Article 104: Inclusion in the trading book
Content: (f) the extent to which the institution can, and is required to, actively manage the risks of positions within its trading operation;

Article: Article 104: Inclusion in the trading book
Content: (g) the extent to which the institution may transfer risk or positions between the non-trading and trading books and the criteria for such transfers.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 1. All trading book positions shall be subject to the standards for prudent valuation specified in this Article. Institutions shall in particular ensure that the prudent valuation of their trading book positions achieves an appropriate degree of certainty having regard to the dynamic nature of trading book positions, the demands of prudential soundness and the mode of operation and purpose of capital requirements in respect of trading book positions.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 2. Institutions shall establish and maintain systems and controls sufficient to provide prudent and reliable valuation estimates. Those systems and controls shall include at least the following elements:

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (a) documented policies and procedures for the process of valuation, including clearly defined responsibilities of the various areas involved in the determination of the valuation, sources of market information and review of their appropriateness, guidelines for the use of unobservable inputs reflecting the institution's assumptions of what market participants would use in pricing the position, frequency of independent valuation, timing of closing prices, procedures for adjusting valuations, month end and ad-hoc verification procedures;

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (b) reporting lines for the department accountable for the valuation process that are clear and independent of the front office, which shall ultimately be to the management body.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 3. Institutions shall revalue trading book positions at least daily.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 4. Institutions shall mark their positions to market whenever possible, including when applying trading book capital treatment.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 5. When marking to market, an institution shall use the more prudent side of bid and offer unless the institution can close out at mid market. Where institutions make use of this derogation, they shall every six months inform their competent authorities of the positions concerned and furnish evidence that they can close out at mid-market.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 6. Where marking to market is not possible, institutions shall conservatively mark to model their positions and portfolios, including when calculating own funds requirements for positions in the trading book.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 7. Institutions shall comply with the following requirements when marking to model:

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (a) senior management shall be aware of the elements of the trading book or of other fair-valued positions which are subject to mark to model and shall understand the materiality of the uncertainty thereby created in the reporting of the risk/performance of the business;

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (b) institutions shall source market inputs, where possible, in line with market prices, and shall assess the appropriateness of the market inputs of the particular position being valued and the parameters of the model on a frequent basis;

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (c) where available, institutions shall use valuation methodologies which are accepted market practice for particular financial instruments or commodities;

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (d) where the model is developed by the institution itself, it shall be based on appropriate assumptions, which have been assessed and challenged by suitably qualified parties independent of the development process;

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (e) institutions shall have in place formal change control procedures and shall hold a secure copy of the model and use it periodically to check valuations;

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (f) risk management shall be aware of the weaknesses of the models used and how best to reflect those in the valuation output; and

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (g) institutions' models shall be subject to periodic review to determine the accuracy of their performance, which shall include assessing the continued appropriateness of assumptions, analysis of profit and loss versus risk factors, and comparison of actual close out values to model outputs.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: For the purposes of point (d), the model shall be developed or approved independently of the trading desk and shall be independently tested, including validation of the mathematics, assumptions and software implementation.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 8. Institutions shall perform independent price verification in addition to daily marking to market or marking to model. Verification of market prices and model inputs shall be performed by a person or unit independent from persons or units that benefit from the trading book, at least monthly, or more frequently depending on the nature of the market or trading activity. Where independent pricing sources are not available or pricing sources are more subjective, prudent measures such as valuation adjustments may be appropriate.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 9. Institutions shall establish and maintain procedures for considering valuation adjustments.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 10. Institutions shall formally consider the following valuation adjustments: unearned credit spreads, close-out costs, operational risks, market price uncertainty, early termination, investing and funding costs, future administrative costs and, where relevant, model risk.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 11. Institutions shall establish and maintain procedures for calculating an adjustment to the current valuation of any less liquid positions, which can in particular arise from market events or institution-related situations such as concentrated positions and/or positions for which the originally intended holding period has been exceeded. Institutions shall, where necessary, make such adjustments in addition to any changes to the value of the position required for financial reporting purposes and shall design such adjustments to reflect the illiquidity of the position. Under those procedures, institutions shall consider several factors when determining whether a valuation adjustment is necessary for less liquid positions. Those factors include the following:

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (a) the amount of time it would take to hedge out the position or the risks within the position;

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (b) the volatility and average of bid/offer spreads;

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (c) the availability of market quotes (number and identity of market makers) and the volatility and average of trading volumes including trading volumes during periods of market stress;

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (d) market concentrations;

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (e) the ageing of positions;

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (f) the extent to which valuation relies on marking-to-model;

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: (g) the impact of other model risks.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 12. When using third party valuations or marking to model, institutions shall consider whether to apply a valuation adjustment. In addition, institutions shall consider the need to establish adjustments for less liquid positions and on an ongoing basis review their continued suitability. Institutions shall also explicitly assess the need for valuation adjustments relating to the uncertainty of parameter inputs used by models.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 13. With regard to complex products, including securitisation exposures and n-th-to-default credit derivatives, institutions shall explicitly assess the need for valuation adjustments to reflect the model risk associated with using a possibly incorrect valuation methodology and the model risk associated with using unobservable (and possibly incorrect) calibration parameters in the valuation model.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: 14. EBA shall develop draft regulatory technical standards to specify the conditions according to which the requirements of Article 105 shall be applied for the purposes of paragraph 1 of this Article.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: EBA shall submit those draft regulatory technical standards to the Commission by 28 July 2013.

Article: Article 105: Requirements for prudent valuation
Content: Power is delegated to the Commission to adopt the regulatory technical standards referred to in the first subparagraph in accordance with Articles 10 to 14 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/ 2010.

Article: Article 106: Internal Hedges
Content: 1. An internal hedge shall in particular meet the following requirements:

Article: Article 106: Internal Hedges
Content: (a) it shall not be primarily intended to avoid or reduce own funds requirements;

Article: Article 106: Internal Hedges
Content: (b) it shall be properly documented and subject to particular internal approval and audit procedures;

Article: Article 106: Internal Hedges
Content: (c) it shall be dealt with at market conditions;

Article: Article 106: Internal Hedges
Content: (d) the market risk that is generated by the internal hedge shall be dynamically managed in the trading book within the authorised limits;

Article: Article 106: Internal Hedges
Content: (e) it shall be carefully monitored in accordance with adequate procedures.

Article: Article 106: Internal Hedges
Content: 2. The requirements of paragraph 1 apply without prejudice to the requirements applicable to the hedged position in the non-trading book.

Article: Article 106: Internal Hedges
Content: 3. By way of derogation from paragraphs 1 and 2, when an institution hedges a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure using a credit derivative booked in its trading book using an internal hedge, the non-trading book exposure or counterparty risk exposure shall not be deemed to be hedged for the purposes of calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts unless the institution purchases from an eligible third party protection provider a corresponding credit derivative meeting the requirements for unfunded credit protection in the non-trading book. Without prejudice to point (h) of Article 299 (2), where such third party protection is purchased and recognised as a hedge of a non-trading book exposure for the purposes of calculating capital requirements, neither the internal nor external credit derivative hedge shall be included in the trading book for the purposes of calculating capital requirements.

Title: TITLE II: CAPITAL REQUIREMENTS FOR CREDIT RISK

Article: Article 107: Approaches to credit risk
Content: 1. Institutions shall apply either the Standardised Approach provided for in Chapter 2 or, if permitted by the competent authorities in accordance with Article 143, the Internal Ratings Based Approach provided for in Chapter 3 to calculate their risk-weighted exposure amounts for the purposes of points (a) and (f) of Article 92(3).

Article: Article 107: Approaches to credit risk
Content: 2. For trade exposures and for default fund contributions to a central counterparty, institutions shall apply the treatment set out in Chapter 6, Section 9 to calculate their risk-weighted exposure amounts for the purposes of points (a) and (f) of Article 92(3). For all other types of exposures to a central counterparty, institutions shall treat those exposures as follows:

Article: Article 107: Approaches to credit risk
Content: (a) as exposures to an institution for other types of exposures to a qualifying CCP;

Article: Article 107: Approaches to credit risk
Content: (b) as exposures to a corporate for other types of exposures to a non-qualifying CCP.

Article: Article 107: Approaches to credit risk
Content: 3. For the purposes of this Regulation, exposures to thirdcountry investment firms and exposures to third country credit institutions and exposures to third country clearing houses and exchanges shall be treated as exposures to an institution only if the third country applies prudential and supervisory requirements to that entity that are at least equivalent to those applied in the Union.

Article: Article 107: Approaches to credit risk
Content: 4. For the purposes of paragraph 3, the Commission may adopt, by way of implementing acts, and subject to the examination procedure referred to in Article 464(2), a decision as to whether a third country applies prudential supervisory and regulatory requirements at least equivalent to those applied in the Union. In the absence of such a decision, until 1 January 2015, institutions may continue to treat exposures to the entities referred to in paragraph 3 as exposures to institutions provided that the relevant competent authorities have approved the third country as eligible for that treatment before 1 January 2014.

Article: Article 108: Use of credit risk mitigation technique under the Standardised Approach and the IRB Approach
Content: 1. For an exposure to which an institution applies the Standardised Approach under Chapter 2 or applies the IRB Approach under Chapter 3 but without using its own estimates of loss given default (LGD) and conversion factors under Article 151, the institution may use credit risk mitigation in accordance with Chapter 4 in the calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts for the purposes of points (a) and (f) of Article 92(3) or, as relevant, expected loss amounts for the purposes of the calculation referred to in point (d) of Article 36(1) and point (c) of Article 62.

Article: Article 108: Use of credit risk mitigation technique under the Standardised Approach and the IRB Approach
Content: 2. For an exposure to which an institution applies the IRB Approach by using their own estimates of LGD and conversion factors under Article 151, the institution may use credit risk mitigation in accordance with Chapter 3.

Article: Article 109: Treatment of securitised exposures under the Standardised Approach and the IRB Approach
Content: 1. Where an institution uses the Standardised Approach under Chapter 2 for the calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts for the exposure class to which the securitised exposures would be assigned under Article 112, it shall calculate the risk-weighted exposure amount for a securitisation position in accordance with Articles 245, 246 and 251 to 258. Institutions using the Standardised Approach may also use the Internal Assessment Approach where this has been permitted under Article 259(3).

Article: Article 109: Treatment of securitised exposures under the Standardised Approach and the IRB Approach
Content: 2. Where an institution uses the IRB Approach under Chapter 3 for the calculation of risk-weighted exposures amounts for the exposure class to which the securitised exposure would be assigned under Article 147 it shall calculate the risk-weighted exposure amount in accordance with Articles 245, 246 and 259 to 266.

Article: Article 109: Treatment of securitised exposures under the Standardised Approach and the IRB Approach
Content: Except for the Internal Assessment Approach, where the IRB Approach is used only for a part of the securitised exposures underlying a securitisation, the institution shall use the approach corresponding to the predominant share of securitised exposures underlying this securitisation.

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: 1. Institutions applying the Standardised Approach shall treat general credit risk adjustments in accordance with Article 62(c).

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: 2. Institutions applying the IRB Approach shall treat general credit risk adjustments in accordance with Article 159, Article 62(d) and Article 36(1)(d).

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: For the purposes of this Article and Chapters 2 and 3, general and specific credit risk adjustments shall exclude funds for general banking risk.

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: 3. Institutions using the IRB Approach that apply the Standardised Approach for a part of their exposures on consolidated or individual basis, in accordance with Articles 148 and 150 shall determine the part of general credit risk adjustment that shall be assigned to the treatment of general credit risk adjustment under the Standardised Approach and to the treatment of general credit risk adjustment under the IRB Approach as follows:

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: (a) where applicable, when an institution included in the consolidation exclusively applies the IRB Approach, general credit risk adjustments of this institution shall be assigned to the treatment set out in paragraph 2;

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: (b) where applicable, when an institution included in the consolidation exclusively applies the Standardised Approach, general credit risk adjustment of this institution shall be assigned to the treatment set out in paragraph 1;

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: (c) the remainder of credit risk adjustment shall be assigned on a pro rata basis according to the proportion of risk weighted exposure amounts subject to the Standardised Approach and subject to the IRB Approach.

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: 4. EBA shall develop draft regulatory technical standards to specify the calculation of specific credit risk adjustments and general credit risk adjustments under the applicable accounting framework for the following:

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: (a) exposure value under the Standardised Approach referred to in Article 111;

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: (b) exposure value under the IRB Approach referred to in Articles 166 to 168;

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: (c) treatment of expected loss amounts referred to in Article 159;

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: (d) exposure value for the calculation of the risk-weighted exposure amounts for securitisation position referred to in Articles 246 and 266;

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: (e) the determination of default under Article 178.

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: EBA shall submit those draft regulatory technical standards to the Commission by 28 July 2013.

Article: Article 110: Treatment of credit risk adjustment
Content: Power is delegated to the Commission to adopt the regulatory technical standards referred to in the first subparagraph in accordance with Articles 10 to 14 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/ 2010.

Article: Article 111: Exposure value
Content: 1. The exposure value of an asset item shall be its accounting value remaining after specific credit risk adjustments, additional value adjustments in accordance with Articles 34 and 110 and other own funds reductions related to the asset item have been applied. The exposure value of an off-balance sheet item listed in Annex I shall be the following percentage of its nominal value after reduction of specific credit risk adjustments:

Article: Article 111: Exposure value
Content: (a) 100 % if it is a full-risk item;

Article: Article 111: Exposure value
Content: (b) 50 % if it is a medium-risk item;

Article: Article 111: Exposure value
Content: (c) 20 % if it is a medium/low-risk item;

Article: Article 111: Exposure value
Content: (d) 0 % if it is a low-risk item.

Article: Article 111: Exposure value
Content: The off-balance sheet items referred to in the second sentence of the first subparagraph shall be assigned to risk categories as indicated in Annex I.

Article: Article 111: Exposure value
Content: When an institution is using the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Method under Article 223, the exposure value of securities or commodities sold, posted or lent under a repurchase transaction or under a securities or commodities lending or borrowing transaction, and margin lending transactions shall be increased by the volatility adjustment appropriate to such securities or commodities as prescribed in Articles 223 to 225.

Article: Article 111: Exposure value
Content: 2. The exposure value of a derivative instrument listed in Annex II shall be determined in accordance with Chapter 6 with the effects of contracts of novation and other netting agreements taken into account for the purposes of those methods in accordance with Chapter 6. The exposure value of repurchase transaction, securities or commodities lending or borrowing transactions, long settlement transactions and margin lending transactions may be determined either in accordance with Chapter 6 or Chapter 4.

Article: Article 111: Exposure value
Content: 3. Where an exposure is subject to funded credit protection, the exposure value applicable to that item may be amended in accordance with Chapter 4.

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: Each exposure shall be assigned to one of the following exposure classes:

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (a) exposures to central governments or central banks;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (b) exposures to regional governments or local authorities;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (c) exposures to public sector entities;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (d) exposures to multilateral development banks;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (e) exposures to international organisations;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (f) exposures to institutions;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (g) exposures to corporates;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (h) retail exposures;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (i) exposures secured by mortgages on immovable property;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (j) exposures in default;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (k) exposures associated with particularly high risk;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (l) exposures in the form of covered bonds;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (m) items representing securitisation positions;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (n) exposures to institutions and corporates with a short-term credit assessment;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (o) exposures in the form of units or shares in collective investment undertakings ("CIUs");

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (p) equity exposures;

Article: Article 112: Exposure classes
Content: (q) other items.

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: 1. To calculate risk-weighted exposure amounts, risk weights shall be applied to all exposures, unless deducted from own funds, in accordance with the provisions of Section 2. The application of risk weights shall be based on the exposure class to which the exposure is assigned and, to the extent specified in Section 2, its credit quality. Credit quality may be determined by reference to the credit assessments of ECAIs or the credit assessments of export credit agencies in accordance with Section 3.

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: 2. For the purposes of applying a risk weight, as referred to in paragraph 1, the exposure value shall be multiplied by the risk weight specified or determined in accordance with Section 2.

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: 3. Where an exposure is subject to credit protection the risk weight applicable to that item may be amended in accordance with Chapter 4.

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: 4. Risk-weighted exposure amounts for securitised exposures shall be calculated in accordance with Chapter 5.

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: 5. Exposures for which no calculation is provided in Section 2 shall be assigned a risk-weight of 100 %.

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: 6. With the exception of exposures giving rise to Common Equity Tier 1, Additional Tier 1 or Tier 2 items, an institution may, subject to the prior approval of the competent authorities, decide not to apply the requirements of paragraph 1 of this Article to the exposures of that institution to a counterparty which is its parent undertaking, its subsidiary, a subsidiary of its parent undertaking or an undertaking linked by a relationship within the meaning of Article 12(1) of Directive 83/349/EEC.

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: Competent authorities are empowered to grant approval if the following conditions are fulfilled:

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: (a) the counterparty is an institution, a financial institution or an ancillary services undertaking subject to appropriate prudential requirements;

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: (b) the counterparty is included in the same consolidation as the institution on a full basis;

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: (c) the counterparty is subject to the same risk evaluation, measurement and control procedures as the institution;

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: (d) the counterparty is established in the same Member State as the institution;

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: (e) there is no current or foreseen material practical or legal impediment to the prompt transfer of own funds or repayment of liabilities from the counterparty to the institution.

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: Where the institution, in accordance with this paragraph, is authorised not to apply the requirements of paragraph 1, it may assign a risk weight of 0 %.

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: 7. With the exception of exposures giving rise to Common Equity Tier 1, Additional Tier 1 and Tier 2 items, institutions may, subject to the prior permission of the competent authorities, not apply the requirements of paragraph 1 of this Article to exposures to counterparties with which the institution has entered into an institutional protection scheme that is a contractual or statutory liability arrangement which protects those institutions and in particular ensures their liquidity and solvency to avoid bankruptcy where necessary. Competent authorities are empowered to grant permission if the following conditions are fulfilled:

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
Content: (a) the requirements set out in points (a), (d) and (e) of paragraph 6 are met;

Article: Article 113: Calculation of risk-weighted exposure amounts
